svg.text: GB of storage on board so the user can store a lot of documents, or even books or articles ​to have read to them. It can even access news, internet radio, and other internet content.​Perhaps the most impressive thing about this device is its connectivity ​capabilities. This device can be connected to just about any electronic you can think of ​and allow a person with vision impairments to use it. For example, using USB ports the ​BrailleNote Apex can be connected to a flash drive to read and open documents, it can ​connect to an external hard drive for larger storage needs, or even a printer to print out ​documents or papers. In addition, the device has Bluetooth capabilities allowing it to ​connect to wireless listening devices or even the user’s smartphone or tablet.​This device can do just about anything that a standard computer can do. And if ​there’s something it can’t do itself it can be connected to a Mac or PC and act as a ​screenreader/keyboard.​3.What prerequisite skills does a person need in order to use the product/service? ​A person using this device should be able to read Braille.​4.If the product is used in conjunction with a computer, are Windows and Mac versions ​available? Are versions for smart phones and other mobile devices available (e.g. ​Blackberry, iPhone, Android, iPad, other tablets, etc.)? If versions are available for ​different devices, are they essentially the same?​The device can be used as a standalone device. But it can also be used with either a Mac ​or PC as well as tablets and smartphones.​5.What qualifications or eligibility criteria, if any, does an individual need to meet in order ​to obtain the product/service (e.g. disability, age/grade level)? What documentation is ​required if there are eligibility criteria?​None.​6.What does the product/service cost? Include information about different options’ costs, if ​available. ​The product is $3,895.​7.Other important information:

Reflection: Your thoughts, comments and lingering questions about this product/service:​I will admit that I spent several minutes staring at the product and several more doing some ​intense research to find out how it worked without any screen attached. Then I realized that ​people with vision impairments don’t need a screen. That’s what makes this device truly ​amazing to me. The fact that it enables someone with low/no vision to check email, take notes ​in school, browse the web, etc. is phenomenal. I thought at first that the price was a bit absurd, ​but after finding out just how much it can do, it is an invaluable technology for someone with a ​vision impairment.
